title: Respect During Conflict
description: Explore how you maintain respect and prevent contempt during disagreements.

questions.text: Even when I'm upset with my partner, I try to...
choices: Remember they're a good person having a hard moment
Avoid saying things I'll regret
Focus on the issue, not attack their character
All of these—respect is non-negotiable

therapeutic.rationale: Maintaining respect during conflict predicts relationship success. Contempt—the opposite of respect—is the single strongest predictor of divorce. These strategies all prevent contempt: seeing the good, restraint, and issue-focus.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these strategies prevent contempt. Different emphases are fine—the key is maintaining fundamental respect during conflict.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared commitment to respect during conflict creates a safe foundation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you maintain respect when you're upset? When is it hardest?

questions.text: When frustrated, I'm most likely to slip into...
choices: Eye-rolling or dismissive body language
Sarcasm or mocking
Harsh words or name-calling
I generally maintain composure

therapeutic.rationale: Contempt shows in various forms. Eye-rolling signals dismissal; sarcasm mocks; harsh words attack. Even maintained composure may hide contempt. Awareness of your contempt signals is the first step to eliminating them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different contempt expressions are all damaging. Be honest about your patterns and work to eliminate them.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared awareness helps you call out contempt when you see it in yourselves.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're frustrated, what behaviors slip out that you're not proud of?

questions.text: If I noticed myself feeling contempt, I'd want to...
choices: Take a break before saying something harmful
Remember what I love about my partner
Examine what's really bothering me underneath
Address it directly—contempt signals something important

therapeutic.rationale: Contempt management strategies all have value. Breaks prevent damage; remembering positives builds fondness; examining underneath finds root issues; addressing directly creates honesty. Contempt that lingers destroys relationships.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different strategies can complement each other. Use multiple approaches when contempt arises.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared strategy creates alignment about how to handle contempt when it surfaces.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Have you ever felt contempt toward your partner? What was really going on underneath?

questions.text: What helps me stay respectful during conflict is...
choices: Remembering we're on the same team
Keeping the big picture in mind
My commitment to never be cruel
Taking breaks when I'm too heated

therapeutic.rationale: Respect maintenance strategies vary. Team-rememberers stay allied; big-picture thinkers keep perspective; commitment-holders have firm values; break-takers regulate. All prevent the escalation that leads to contempt.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different strategies can all work. Share what helps you so your partner understands your approach.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared strategies create aligned coping during conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you stay respectful when you're upset? What would help even more?

questions.text: The line I never want to cross during conflict is...
choices: Personal attacks or name-calling
Bringing up things that will deeply wound
Threatening the relationship
Any of these—all are off-limits

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict boundaries protect relationships. Personal attacks damage; deep wounds cause lasting harm; relationship threats create insecurity. Having explicit off-limits behaviors prevents irreparable damage during heated moments.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these lines are important. Agree on your shared off-limits list before conflict happens.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared boundaries create clear rules of engagement that protect your relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What lines should never be crossed in your conflicts? Have you ever crossed them?
